intro: Cullen walkingtonii, commonly known as the St. Helena cullen, is a rare and endemic flowering plant native to the island of St. Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its distinctive trifoliate leaves and small, pea-like flowers. The plant is adapted to the unique climate and soil conditions of its island habitat, which is relatively isolated and has a subtropical climate. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in preserving its natural environment.
